metadata.description: Clinically accurate synthetic PA cases with embedded compensating factor patterns for AI pattern discovery

Cigna: Requires fecal calprotectin for IBD cases (policy effective 2024-01-01)
Average decision time: 7 days for complete submissions
UnitedHealthcare: Requires documented CDAI/HBI for Crohn's, Mayo for UC
Average decision time: 5 days for complete submissions

appeal_patterns.insight: Appeals within 7 days of denial with additional documentation have highest success rate

severity_overrides_tb_screening.description: High disease severity (CRP >15, fistula, CDAI >300) compensates for missing TB screening

attestation_overrides_step_therapy.description: Physician severity attestation with documented urgency compensates for incomplete step therapy

endoscopy_overrides_fecal_calprotectin.description: Recent endoscopy with documented active disease compensates for missing fecal calprotectin

lab_severity_bundle.description: CRP >20 + albumin <3.0 + ESR >40 as severity bundle increases approval even with gaps

clinical_accuracy_notes: ICD-10 codes match official Crohn's (K50.x) and UC (K51.x) classifications
Disease severity scores use validated instruments (CDAI, HBI, Mayo, UCEIS)
Step therapy reflects real-world biologic sequencing requirements
Lab values (CRP, fecal calprotectin, albumin) within clinically expected ranges
Prior treatment durations reflect minimum therapeutic trial requirements
Compensating factor patterns reflect real-world payer behavior where severe disease can override documentation gaps

primary_patterns: Missing TB screening + CRP>15 + severe classification → 78% approval (vs 45% without severity)
Incomplete step therapy + physician attestation + urgency docs → 82% approval
Missing fecal calprotectin + recent endoscopy showing active disease → 75% approval
Lab severity bundle (CRP>20, albumin<3.0, ESR>40) → 85% approval regardless of other gaps
actionable_insights: When TB screening is pending, emphasize disease severity markers to increase approval likelihood
Physician attestation with urgency documentation can bypass standard step therapy requirements
Recent endoscopy is a strong substitute for fecal calprotectin
Multiple elevated inflammatory markers create a severity bundle that improves approval odds

diagnosis.description: Crohn's disease of small intestine with intestinal obstruction

cases.notes: Approved despite missing TB screening due to severe disease requiring urgent treatment. CRP and disease activity scores documented high severity. Fecal calprotectin waived; endoscopy within 180 days documented active mucosal disease. Lab severity bundle (CRP>20, albumin<3.0, ESR>40) documented - approved under medical necessity.
